data.title: Provide an option to hide the activity bar
data.body:
Implements https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1105

Adds the setting `workbench.activityBar.visible` that allows the user to toggle the activity bar visibility.
Adds the action `workbench.action.toggleActivityBarVisibility` that allows the user to toggle the activity bar visibility with a keybinding or an extension to toggle the visibility through a command.

![2016-11-03_17-23-12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1903871/19986573/a8400414-a1ed-11e6-81d8-297450faf7da.gif)

data.title: Allow multiple sibling names in exclude pattern
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1611

Steps to Reproduce:

It's nice to exclude generated files. e.g.:
`"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).ts" }`
However, `.tsx` files are also compiled to `.js` files, so we need something like this:
`"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).{ts,tsx}" }`
But this doesn't work. VSCode does not exclude any `.js` files with this rule.

Can't add another rule like this:
```
"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).ts" }
"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).tsx" }
```
Because this is invalid JSON (two properties having the same name).

Right now, the workaround is to tweak the second rule a little:
```
"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).ts" }
"**/*.{js}": { "when": "$(basename).tsx" }
```
If more than two file types can be compiled to the same type of output file, you will have to be creative, e.g. `**/*.{j}{s}`.

data.title: HTML attributes containing values with *.ref* break syntax highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Win 10

With HTML syntax highlighting, having a value of an element attribute that contains `*.ref*` breaks syntax highlighting as if the quotation containing the value never closes. This has only happened with the `*.ref*` so far.

This issue is likely to show up when using JS frameworks, like Aurelia, and you bind object properties to HTML attributes.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set syntax highlighting to HTML
2. Paste in `<div data-reference-id="client.referenceId">`

You can see that the quotation containing `client.referenceId` is never closed as for syntax highlighting. I've tested it in several color themes and it doesn't seem to be related to that.

![vscode-html-higlight-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1162364/19986133/c2069e6c-a215-11e6-8f75-8aaa00b5cc0d.jpg)

data.title: Installing extensions from my dotfiles
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: OSX Siera: 10.12.1 (16B2555)

I used to install all my extensions with the following script:

```
# installation of extensions
for VARIANT in "code"
do
  if hash $VARIANT 2>/dev/null; then
    VERSION="$($VARIANT --version)"
    MAJOR="$(echo $VERSION | sed -e 's/\..*$//')"
    MINOR="$(echo $VERSION | sed -e 's/\-[a-z]*$//' -e 's/^[0-9]*\.//' -e 's/\.[0-9]*$//')"
    if [ "$MAJOR" -gt "0" ] && [ "$MINOR" -gt "1" ]; then
      echo "Installing extensions for $VARIANT"
      for EXTENSION in ${EXTENSIONS[@]}
      do
        $VARIANT --install-extension $EXTENSION
      done
    else
      echo "$VARIANT (v$VERSION) does not support extension CLI args"
    fi
  fi
done

```

Unfortunately this does not work anymore. I'm unsure what version caused this; but do you guys have any idea how to fix this? 

![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 22 03 16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3907131/19985101/5f674152-a211-11e6-93f6-8dc40f8b68e1.png)

data.title: Plugin installation stalls when /tmp is full

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1 02611b4
- OS Version: Arch

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fill /tmp so that it has 0 bytes left
2. Try installing a plugin

Expected:

A message about being unable to install a plugin due to /tmp being full.

Actual:

Plugin installation stalls with button in `Installing` state without any progress or other feedback.

data.title: VSCode should not open browser on first start without user's say-so
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1 02611b40b
- OS Version: Arch

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install `visual-studio-code` from AUR
2. Open installed application.

Upon first start vscode opens a web browser pointing to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs?start=true. It should not do that without getting a confirmation from user it is OK to do so.

Some editors choose to have a "welcome" page with links to documentation (cf. Eclipse, Qt Creator), it could be one possible solution.

Perhaps a MD/RST document could be opened upon first start with some brief info and helpful links (cf. Vim, Emacs).

Another option would be a prompt asking user to open a link could do as well, but personally I think this would be worse solution.

data.title: Allow "OPEN EDITORS" frame to be expanded down
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: all

In the absence of vertically arranged tabs, it would be nice if the "OPEN EDITORS" frame could be expanded downwards, thus shrinking the frame containing the project directory tree. Currently it is fixed at a fairly small level, meaning if you have lots of open files only a subset are displayed. It is strange the bar separating the two frames is not adjustable.

data.title: Hygiene check on Windows fails due to CRLF even if core.autocrlf is set to true
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 version 1607

When trying to commit to the VSCode code base on Windows I recieve this error:
```
{file}: Missing or bad copyright statement
{file} is not formatted
```
This seems to have been fixed in the past (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/3835 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1642) by checking if core.autocrlf is set to true but it looks like the recent addition of typescript-formatter (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/81de8be588ff7f0e62f5e98be2a2c551b7f65d44) breaks this again. The copyright issue is pretty easily fixable by using `os.EOL` instead of `\n` in gulpfile.hygiene.js (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/d14ee7613fcead91c5c3c2bddbf288c0462be876/build/gulpfile.hygiene.js#L99).

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use Windows and make sure core.autocrlf is set to true
2. Make a code change that includes a new line
3. Attempt to commit the change
4. You will recieve the error
```
src\vs\workbench\electron-browser\workbench.ts: Missing or bad copyright statement
C:\Users\Sanders\Documents\GitHub\vscode\src\vs\workbench\electron-browser\workbench.ts is not formatted
```

I was able to work around this temporarily by setting core.autocrlf to `input` instead of `true` and then switching all the line endings for files I've changed to LF instead of CRLF.

data.title: VSCode Upgrade Linux 64bit tries to install 32bit deps
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Fedora 24 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. install previous version of vscode (e.g. 1.6.1)
2. download and upgrade rpm using 'yum install vscode171.rpm'

Observe packages to be isntalled/upgraded:
=========================
Installing:
 glibc                    i686         2.23.1-10.fc24             updates            4.3 M
 libX11                   i686         1.6.3-3.fc24               fedora             616 k
 libXScrnSaver            i686         1.2.2-10.fc24              fedora              28 k
 libXau                   i686         1.0.8-6.fc24               fedora              34 k
 libXext                  i686         1.3.3-4.fc24               fedora              43 k
 libxcb                   i686         1.11.1-2.fc24              fedora             205 k
 nss-softokn-freebl       i686         3.27.0-1.0.fc24            updates            209 k
Upgrading:
 code                     x86_64       1.7.1-1478180561.el7       @commandline        48 M
=========================

There is no good reason a 64bit package should be trying to install 32bit deps it can't possibly be linking against. This is annoying as I don't want to have any 32bit crap on my system.

data.title: editor.action.insertCursorAtEndOfEachLineSelected command should only put cursors on lines that have text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. select multiple lines including empty lines
2. invoke the editor.action.insertCursorAtEndOfEachLineSelected command

Notice that cursors are placed on all lines including those that don't have any text. Most use cases for this feature are only interested in editing lines that have text so this should be the default.

data.title: Allow "Insert Cursor" keybinding to be configurable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra

It does not appear that the Insert Cursor keybinding can be configurable. I would like to map it to the Sublimetext equivalent which is ```cmd+click```

Thanks.

data.title: Allow interpolation coloring in template literal strings when using new JS/TS grammar
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.7.0 (or pre-1.7 with new grammar extension) - OS Version: Windows 10 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Write a template literal string with interpolation: \`test ${var}\` 2. Before the new grammar was introduced, interpolation received special coloring 3. Post new grammar, interpolation is colored the same as the rest of the string Personally, I find this far less readable when scanning template strings; I have to look more carefully than before to pick out where I'm interpolating an expression. Is there a way we can return the old coloring while respecting the new design decisions behind the grammar rewrite?

data.title: Proxy configuration doesn't work in VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm testing VSCode by first time and I configure my proxy in settings.json as recommended:

"http.proxy": "http://domain\\user:pass@myproxy:port/"

But it doesn't work when I try to install new extensions I get a connected timeout error. I also try to configure the proxy as system enviroment variable with the same result.
Could you help me?Is it a bug or I'm doing something wrong?
Is there another way to download extensions?

Thank you very much!

data.title: Use debug adapter completions to improve IntelliSense in editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Currently your able to inspect the current scoped variables, and write code whilst you have hit a break point. Would be a neat idea do be able to complement these with Intellisense autocomplete, since your currently at a breakpoint and you can see the types of variables anyway.
